CAPTAIN GEORGE M. GILLETT.
The line-up:

Herbert Catlin, '14, was elected
captain of the 'Varsity track team
last Monday afternoon at a meeting of last year's track squad held
in the trophy room of the gymnasium. William Norman Brown
also ran for the position of captain.
Catlin has made quite a record
for himself in track athletics and
also as a football player since he
entered the University in the fall
of 1910. Having had some experience in these branches of athletics
while at the Kent School, he at
once became a likely 'Varsity player at Hopkins. He was a substitute on the 'Varsity football team
in his freshman year and quarterback of the freshman eleven. In
the annual sophomore:- freshman
indoor track meet he won both the
mile and half-mile runs in fine
shape.
As a regular 'Varsity player, Catlin won his "H" in football in his
sophomore.year. He was also captain and quarterback of his class
team. He repeated his victories of
.the preceding year in the interclass meet. Last spring, with the
exception of Freddie Lee, Catlin
was the best distance runner in the
Black and Blue squad.
He won his "H" in track athletics by finishing first in the mile
run in the dual meet with Swarthmore. He placed third in the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate championships.
An ambitious schedule of dual
meets is being arranged by Manager Paul 0. Carter. The majority
of the members of last year's team
are back at the University, and
track prospects are very bright.
Among the veterans who are expected to compete again this season

Drawings of Gilman Building in Hands
of Contractors—Location of
Structures to Be Shifted.

"Plans for the Gilman Building,
the main building of the new University on the Homewood Estate,
have been approved by the' Board
of Trustees and 'faculty and will
soon be placed in the hands of the
contractors." This is the substance
of a statement made by a member
of the faculty in touch with the
Homewood operations.
Parker, Thomas & Rice, local
architects, prepared the plans and
submitted them to. the trustees.
This body approved them, provided
they met with the sanction of the
faculty, and they were placed in
Librarian Raney's office, where the
faculty might examine them.
It is understood that the department heads and other professors
found the blueprints highly satisfactory and far superior to previous
drawings. The architects are now
preparing complete specifications
and building plans to be submitted
to contractors for bidding.
As soon as these contracts are let,
the erection of the building will be
commenced. It is believed that
this will be done before next
spring.
The Gilman Building, named in
memory of Daniel Coit Gilman, the
University's first president, will
correspond with McCoy Hall, except that the library and assembly
hall will be put in other buildings. The style of architecture
will be Colonial, the key being the
Carroll Mansion now standing on
the Homewood Estate. The building will be constructed around a
court and will form the west end
of the quadrangle. The north and
south sides of the quadrangle will
be made up of the four scientific buildings and laboratories, and
the Administration Building will
close the "quad" on the east end.
To the north of where the Administration Building will be erected stands the Carroll Mansion, and
it is said that the mansion will be
made a museum of Maryland history. On the south side of the Administration Building and directly
facing the Carroll home will be a
replica of the Carroll building,
which will be the president's residence. It will be some time, however, before this will be put up.
The technical buildings will extend southwards from the quadrangle and parallel to Charles Street
avenue. On the northern side of
the quadrangle will be the Young
Men's Christian Association Build(Continued on page 7, col. I.)

is on the staff of the Indianapolis
Sun.
Rev. Whitford L. McDowell, D.
D., pastor of the Roland Park M.
E. Church, was the representative
of the Johns Hopkins University
at the inauguration of Dr. Ezra
Squier Tipple as president of • the
Drew Theological Seminary last
Thursday week. Dr. McDowell
was an undergraduate here in the
Class of '91.
The former chief of the Division
of Chemistry, Hygiene Laboratory,
Marine Hospital Service at Washinvton, Joseph Hoeing Kastle, Ph.
D. '88. has lately been appointed
director of the experimental station and Dean of the College of
Agriculture at the Kentucky State
College, Lexington, Ky. Dr. Kastle
was a fellow at Hopkins in 1887.
The wedding of Dr. Bernard C.
Steiner, Ph. D., '91, librarian of the
Enoch Pratt Free Library of Baltimore,to Miss Ethel Simes Mulligan,
will take place in St. John's Protestant Epicopal Church, Yonkers, N.
Y., at 3 P. M., November 7. A small
reception will follow at the home
of the bride. Dr. Steiner was at
one time associate in history at the
University.
Bill Gail, '12, has left Massachusetts Institute of Technology and
has accepted a position on a farm
in Iowa. Bill made the change on
account of his health, as he thinks
the out-door life will be more beneficial to him. Jimmy Easter, '12,
who entered the "Tech" with Bill
Gail, is still there and plugging
hard.
Our only Chinese undergraduate
student, Hsueh Wu Sun, Class of
1915, decided, because of the uncertainties of Baltimore climate, not
to return to Hopkins this year, but
to take up his work at Harvard.
Sun was one of the Chinese "Indemnity Fund" students. When in
his native land, he abides in the
City of We ?:, H ??r, W:.§??. It
must be somewhere near Chow
Chow Hang Ho.
It is said that Harold Herring,
Rhodes Scholar from Maryland, has
become quite husky since he has
been abroad. Those who remember the 140-pound senior of two
years ago are astonished to learn
that he now tips the scale at 170.
"Chick" was one of the Oriel College (Oxford) crew last year, and
his shell won nine of the ten races
of the season, being defeated once
at the Henley Regatta by the crew
which finally won the championship.
The faculty of the University of
North Carolina have abolished
senior graduating theses.

Triangle Formed Between Hopkins, Virginia and North Carolina—May
Debate on Neutral Ground.

Arrangements are well under
way for the regular intercollegiate
debates next spring. A triangular league has been formed between
Hopkins, the University of Virginia
and the University of North Carolina, and negotiations are now going on for the settlement of details.
Both Virginia and North Carolina
devote considerable attention to debating, and it is expected that they
will prove rivals well able to test
the mettle of any team that Hopkins can put into the field.
A tentative proposal of terms has
been submitted to North Carolina
and Hopkins by Virginia. In this
proposal the novel suggestion is advanced that all three of the debates
be held on neutral ground; in other
words, that Hopkins debate Virginia at North Carolina and North
Carolina at Virginia, and that the
Virginia - North Carolina contest
take place in Baltimore. This arrangement will undoubtedly meet
with the approval of all three institutions.
It is hoped that an agreement can
be reached restricting the membership of the teams to men who have
not yet received a degree. Both Virginia and North Carolina have large
professional schools, and such an
agreement would not disqualify the
members of these schools who have
not had a collegiate course. If the
agreement cannot be reached, however, and graduate students should
be eligible, there are a number of
men in our graduate department
who are trained debaters and whose
services would add tremendous
strength to the teams.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 4, 1912
The Football Situation.

Despite the apparently unfortunate showing in points made by
the football team this year, there
is no reason at all to feel that the
team deserves anything but praise.
Hopkins is so situated that its
students play football under difficulties. The laboratories are located
four miles from the playing field,
and the men after working until
five o'clock in the one, have a fortyfive minute car ride ahead of them
-before they can reach the other.
They come onto the field fatigued
and after the sun has gone down,
and as a consequence, are unable
to practice with the snap and vigor
which makes practice really worth
while.
It must be remembered, moreover, that a large part of the team
this year happens to be made up
of new men. A great number of
players who were for years the
mainstay of Hopkins football
dropped out at the close of last
season. Their successors will in
all probability turn out to be just
as efficient men in the long run, but
at present they are more or less
raw.
The third disadvantage we are
up against this year is the schedule. The wonderfully successful
teams of the last three years have
lifted Hopkins into a class of colleges which our present inexperienced team is as yet unable to
handle. As it is, the showing made
against the Navy was little short
of miraculous. No one could expect that it would be kept up. The
defeat of the team by the heavy
elevens of Franklin and Marshall
and of Swarthmore was no more
than could have been looked for.
The critical games of the season—those against Western Maryland and St. John's—are ahead of
us. Both of these institutions, in
the revolution of fate, happen to

Captain Gillett's Injury.

wear

. The painful injury received by
Captain Gillett in last Saturday's
game is a matter of regret to the
entire University. Entirely apart
from the effect which it will have
upon the team, we are all sorry
for •the accident for Gillie's own
sake. Whenever a man receives an
injury while fighting in the common cause, there is something
noble in the spectacle; and the man
himself deserves so much the more
of sympathy and admiration. Gillie
was hurt in Hopkins' cause, and
Hopkins men should appreciate his
sacrifice accordingly. I fe has given
the full measure of his time and
energy to University athletics in
the past; he now adds the full
measure of pain and suffering. We
wish him an easy and speedy recovery.

The Woodrow Wilson advocate
is doubtless a man of affairs, but
his good-humor and obliging disposion are certainly shown, for did
he not give up a few valuable moments to "dictate" his opinions for
publication? Here we see a budding statesman, with a private secretary, a future Boswell always
present, to take down the thoughts
of the man of embryonic greatness.
But the Taft statement was not
dictated. That contains erudite
references to the sudden demise of
Alexander Hainilton and the grave
of Daniel Webster. Thought was
required; an hour's research in the
library was necessary, before the
classic allusions of this interview
could be verified. Who will say
that it was not worth while? The
arguments, concisely put, according
to the rules of English Composition I, form a poetic whole and
deserve to be copied widely in the
Taft press. I have no doubt but
that they will be.
The good work has been started;
by all means _ keep it up. THE
NEWS-LETTER should print more interviews, embracing a wider variety
of subjects, for instance: "The
Suppression .of the White Slave
Traffic," "The Presidency of Hopkins," "Who Hit Jack Robinson,"
"The Age of Ann," "Physics I,"
"The Trouble With the Football
Team," "The Rule of the Bosses in

Various Females Around - IcCoy
Hall," "The War in the Balkans,"
'How to Pick Up a Chorus Girl,"
"Policemen Versus Firemen: Their
Value to the Community," "How
to Play Poker and Win," "Getting
a Degree Without Study," and so
on almost indefinitely.

offer the modest contribution of

to the man exuding the best interview. I should like to make my
contribution larger, but lack of
knowledge about the next to the
last subject suggested above, compels me to have millionaire inclinations and thirty-cent possibilities,

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 4, 1912.
Dr. Hollander Speaks.

Those who were fortunate enough
to attend a meeting held at Albaugh's Theatre last Monday night
under the auspices of the Progressive League of Maryland, heard
among other spirited addresses an
excellent one from the presiding
officer, Prof. Jacob H. Hollander
of the faculty.
In his speech, Prof. Hollander
expressed in no mincing terms the
need for a new party and his
reasons. "Why in this juncture
even a book-man will leave his
closet to give whatever of strength
there is in him in espousal of the
principles of the Progressive Party
and in advocacy of its aspirations."
He said, in part: "Government
exists as never before for the welfare of the governed. . . . No
leadership has a right to endure
wherein any other ideal is striven
for; and that is why so many like
myself denounce the old political
Parties as bankrupt. . . . The
old parties offer no contributions in
solution of the present terrible economic conditions. The Republican
Party urges a policy of political
quietism. . . . The Democratic
Party contents itself with a policy
of negation, offering a panacea, a
Philosophical creed and an abstract
definition of political structure. As
against such hollow professions
stands the Progressive movement
• • . a veritable Magna Charta
of social justice and industrial well
being. To those. who believe in the
cause of human betterment, its
cause is imperious and irresistible."

Dr James W. Bright of the English literature department read a
paper on "The Authenticity of
Poetry" before the Eclectic Club of
Baltimore on Monday, October 21.

The Western Maryland and the
St. John's football games which
will be played next Saturday and
Saturday following at Homewood
are the games which the Johns Hop-.
kins football team is most anxious
to win.
Western Maryland defeated Hopkins in football last Thanksgiving
Day and won the state football
championship after the Hopkins
had apparently clinched the state
title by defeating Maryland Agricultural and St. John's. This was
the first time that Hopkins had been
defeated by a state eleven for three
years. Hopkins got back at Western Maryland by defeating the
Westminster nine in baseball last
spring. This, however, only served
to increase the rivalry between the
two institutions.
From the showing made by both
Western Maryland and Hopkins in
the games played up to the present
time everything seems to indicate
a very close and hard-fought game.
The Western Maryland students are
coming to Homewood almost to a
man to root for their team. A very
large crowd is expected at the game.
The St. John's game, on November 16, should be the closest game
of a number of years. St. John's
should be the winner on the showing made so far this season, but
Hopkins can be depended upon not
to drop this game without a desperate struggle.

Herbert Catlin, '14, was elected
captain of the 'Varsity track team
last Monday afternoon at a meeting of last year's track squad held
in the trophy room of the gymnasium. William Norman Brown
also ran for the position of captain.
Catlin has made quite a record
for himself in track athletics and
also as a football player since he
entered the University in the fall
of 1910. Having had some experience in these branches of athletics
while at the Kent School, he at
once became a likely 'Varsity player at Hopkins. He was a substitute on the 'Varsity football team
in his freshman year and quarterback of the freshman eleven. In
the annual sophomore:- freshman
indoor track meet he won both the
mile and half-mile runs in fine
shape.
As a regular 'Varsity player, Catlin won his "H" in football in his
sophomore.year. He was also captain and quarterback of his class
team. He repeated his victories of
.the preceding year in the interclass meet. Last spring, with the
exception of Freddie Lee, Catlin
was the best distance runner in the
Black and Blue squad.
He won his "H" in track athletics by finishing first in the mile
run in the dual meet with Swarthmore. He placed third in the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate championships.
An ambitious schedule of dual
meets is being arranged by Manager Paul 0. Carter. The majority
of the members of last year's team
are back at the University, and
track prospects are very bright.
Among the veterans who are expected to compete again this season

Drawings of Gilman Building in Hands
of Contractors—Location of
Structures to Be Shifted.

"Plans for the Gilman Building,
the main building of the new University on the Homewood Estate,
have been approved by the' Board
of Trustees and 'faculty and will
soon be placed in the hands of the
contractors." This is the substance
of a statement made by a member
of the faculty in touch with the
Homewood operations.
Parker, Thomas & Rice, local
architects, prepared the plans and
submitted them to. the trustees.
This body approved them, provided
they met with the sanction of the
faculty, and they were placed in
Librarian Raney's office, where the
faculty might examine them.
It is understood that the department heads and other professors
found the blueprints highly satisfactory and far superior to previous
drawings. The architects are now
preparing complete specifications
and building plans to be submitted
to contractors for bidding.
As soon as these contracts are let,
the erection of the building will be
commenced. It is believed that
this will be done before next
spring.
The Gilman Building, named in
memory of Daniel Coit Gilman, the
University's first president, will
correspond with McCoy Hall, except that the library and assembly
hall will be put in other buildings. The style of architecture
will be Colonial, the key being the
Carroll Mansion now standing on
the Homewood Estate. The building will be constructed around a
court and will form the west end
of the quadrangle. The north and
south sides of the quadrangle will
be made up of the four scientific buildings and laboratories, and
the Administration Building will
close the "quad" on the east end.
To the north of where the Administration Building will be erected stands the Carroll Mansion, and
it is said that the mansion will be
made a museum of Maryland history. On the south side of the Administration Building and directly
facing the Carroll home will be a
replica of the Carroll building,
which will be the president's residence. It will be some time, however, before this will be put up.
The technical buildings will extend southwards from the quadrangle and parallel to Charles Street
avenue. On the northern side of
the quadrangle will be the Young
Men's Christian Association Build(Continued on page 7, col. I.)

Triangle Formed Between Hopkins, Virginia and North Carolina—May
Debate on Neutral Ground.

Arrangements are well under
way for the regular intercollegiate
debates next spring. A triangular league has been formed between
Hopkins, the University of Virginia
and the University of North Carolina, and negotiations are now going on for the settlement of details.
Both Virginia and North Carolina
devote considerable attention to debating, and it is expected that they
will prove rivals well able to test
the mettle of any team that Hopkins can put into the field.
A tentative proposal of terms has
been submitted to North Carolina
and Hopkins by Virginia. In this
proposal the novel suggestion is advanced that all three of the debates
be held on neutral ground; in other
words, that Hopkins debate Virginia at North Carolina and North
Carolina at Virginia, and that the
Virginia - North Carolina contest
take place in Baltimore. This arrangement will undoubtedly meet
with the approval of all three institutions.
It is hoped that an agreement can
be reached restricting the membership of the teams to men who have
not yet received a degree. Both Virginia and North Carolina have large
professional schools, and such an
agreement would not disqualify the
members of these schools who have
not had a collegiate course. If the
agreement cannot be reached, however, and graduate students should
be eligible, there are a number of
men in our graduate department
who are trained debaters and whose
services would add tremendous
strength to the teams.

The Football Situation.

Despite the apparently unfortunate showing in points made by
the football team this year, there
is no reason at all to feel that the
team deserves anything but praise.
Hopkins is so situated that its
students play football under difficulties. The laboratories are located
four miles from the playing field,
and the men after working until
five o'clock in the one, have a fortyfive minute car ride ahead of them
-before they can reach the other.
They come onto the field fatigued
and after the sun has gone down,
and as a consequence, are unable
to practice with the snap and vigor
which makes practice really worth
while.
It must be remembered, moreover, that a large part of the team
this year happens to be made up
of new men. A great number of
players who were for years the
mainstay of Hopkins football
dropped out at the close of last
season. Their successors will in
all probability turn out to be just
as efficient men in the long run, but
at present they are more or less
raw.
The third disadvantage we are
up against this year is the schedule. The wonderfully successful
teams of the last three years have
lifted Hopkins into a class of colleges which our present inexperienced team is as yet unable to
handle. As it is, the showing made
against the Navy was little short
of miraculous. No one could expect that it would be kept up. The
defeat of the team by the heavy
elevens of Franklin and Marshall
and of Swarthmore was no more
than could have been looked for.
The critical games of the season—those against Western Maryland and St. John's—are ahead of
us. Both of these institutions, in
the revolution of fate, happen to

Captain Gillett's Injury.

wear

. The painful injury received by
Captain Gillett in last Saturday's
game is a matter of regret to the
entire University. Entirely apart
from the effect which it will have
upon the team, we are all sorry
for •the accident for Gillie's own
sake. Whenever a man receives an
injury while fighting in the common cause, there is something
noble in the spectacle; and the man
himself deserves so much the more
of sympathy and admiration. Gillie
was hurt in Hopkins' cause, and
Hopkins men should appreciate his
sacrifice accordingly. I fe has given
the full measure of his time and
energy to University athletics in
the past; he now adds the full
measure of pain and suffering. We
wish him an easy and speedy recovery.
Tip: NEWS-LETTER is glad at all
times to receive letters from its
alumni readers. We are sure that
some of the former students of the
University who are still interested
in their alma mater, must have an
opinion about football, the Musical
Clubs and the other University
activities; and we are equally sure
that any criticisms that they should
desire to make, or suggestion that
they should like to offer, would be
appreciated by the men now connected with these things in the
University. We feel that such letters' would add greatly to the interest and value of 'THE NEWS-

The Woodrow Wilson advocate
is doubtless a man of affairs, but
his good-humor and obliging disposion are certainly shown, for did
he not give up a few valuable moments to "dictate" his opinions for
publication? Here we see a budding statesman, with a private secretary, a future Boswell always
present, to take down the thoughts
of the man of embryonic greatness.
But the Taft statement was not
dictated. That contains erudite
references to the sudden demise of
Alexander Hainilton and the grave
of Daniel Webster. Thought was
required; an hour's research in the
library was necessary, before the
classic allusions of this interview
could be verified. Who will say
that it was not worth while? The
arguments, concisely put, according
to the rules of English Composition I, form a poetic whole and
deserve to be copied widely in the
Taft press. I have no doubt but
that they will be.
The good work has been started;
by all means _ keep it up. THE
NEWS-LETTER should print more interviews, embracing a wider variety
of subjects, for instance: "The
Suppression .of the White Slave
Traffic," "The Presidency of Hopkins," "Who Hit Jack Robinson,"
"The Age of Ann," "Physics I,"
"The Trouble With the Football
Team," "The Rule of the Bosses in
Baltimore," "The Merits of '606;"
"The Comparative Beauty of the
Various Females Around - IcCoy
Hall," "The War in the Balkans,"
'How to Pick Up a Chorus Girl,"
"Policemen Versus Firemen: Their
Value to the Community," "How
to Play Poker and Win," "Getting
a Degree Without Study," and so
on almost indefinitely.
If this policy is followed by THE
NEWS-LETTER, I Will be glad to
offer the modest contribution of
five cents to start a fund to be'given
to the man exuding the best interview. I should like to make my
contribution larger, but lack of
knowledge about the next to the
last subject suggested above, compels me to have millionaire inclinations and thirty-cent possibilities,
however incongruous they may be.
But such is the life of one of your
subscribers who is a

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 4, 1912.
Dr. Hollander Speaks.

Those who were fortunate enough
to attend a meeting held at Albaugh's Theatre last Monday night
under the auspices of the Progressive League of Maryland, heard
among other spirited addresses an
excellent one from the presiding
officer, Prof. Jacob H. Hollander
of the faculty.
In his speech, Prof. Hollander
expressed in no mincing terms the
need for a new party and his
reasons. "Why in this juncture
even a book-man will leave his
closet to give whatever of strength
there is in him in espousal of the
principles of the Progressive Party
and in advocacy of its aspirations."
He said, in part: "Government
exists as never before for the welfare of the governed. . . . No
leadership has a right to endure
wherein any other ideal is striven
for; and that is why so many like
myself denounce the old political
Parties as bankrupt. . . . The
old parties offer no contributions in
solution of the present terrible economic conditions. The Republican
Party urges a policy of political
quietism. . . . The Democratic
Party contents itself with a policy
of negation, offering a panacea, a
Philosophical creed and an abstract
definition of political structure. As
against such hollow professions
stands the Progressive movement
• • . a veritable Magna Charta
of social justice and industrial well
being. To those. who believe in the
cause of human betterment, its
cause is imperious and irresistible."

Dr James W. Bright of the English literature department read a
paper on "The Authenticity of
Poetry" before the Eclectic Club of
Baltimore on Monday, October 21.
Dr. Bright will probably publish the
paper.

The Western Maryland and the
St. John's football games which
will be played next Saturday and
Saturday following at Homewood
are the games which the Johns Hop-.
kins football team is most anxious
to win.
Western Maryland defeated Hopkins in football last Thanksgiving
Day and won the state football
championship after the Hopkins
had apparently clinched the state
title by defeating Maryland Agricultural and St. John's. This was
the first time that Hopkins had been
defeated by a state eleven for three
years. Hopkins got back at Western Maryland by defeating the
Westminster nine in baseball last
spring. This, however, only served
to increase the rivalry between the
two institutions.
From the showing made by both
Western Maryland and Hopkins in
the games played up to the present
time everything seems to indicate
a very close and hard-fought game.
The Western Maryland students are
coming to Homewood almost to a
man to root for their team. A very
large crowd is expected at the game.
The St. John's game, on November 16, should be the closest game
of a number of years. St. John's
should be the winner on the showing made so far this season, but
Hopkins can be depended upon not
to drop this game without a desperate struggle.
